          <lb/>not find fuel enough in this clayey world to feed it</seg>

<seg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xml:id="ANN015" ana="a:misquotation" source="bibliography.xml#Butler_Analogy">It is well to be ware of the delu- 
          <lb break="no"/>sion of <hi rend="underline()">feelings</hi>—what are called <hi rend="underline()">frames</hi>— And in every 
          <lb/>ssubject there <hi rend="underline()">may</hi> be delusion. In the speculations of the most 
          <lb/>prolific brain on the deepest, are often errors of immense 
          <lb/>size, obvious to the <choice>
                     <orig>plainst</orig>
                     <reg>plainest</reg>
                  </choice> sense— In every science, in every 
          <lb/>department of philosophy, save experimental (poor sensible
          <lb/>manual experiment) there has been found deceptions 
          <lb/>& errors from the wildest to the most <choice>
                     <orig>desipacable</orig>
                     <reg>despicable</reg>
                  </choice> kind. 
          <lb/>Then where is certainty and what are its surest li- 
          <lb break="no"/>mits? Why not <hi rend="underline()">in feeling</hi>? We all know <choice>
                     <orig>whither</orig>
                     <reg>whether</reg>
                  </choice> we 
          <lb/>are at ease, whether suffering the nameless pangs of
          <lb/>restlessness, ill humour and dreaded apathy, or <subst>
                     <del>these</del>
                     <add>tasting</add>
                  </subst>
                  <lb/>the indiscrible joys of sympathy, benvolence & activity. 
          <lb/>Here is <hi rend="underline()">experiment</hi> in the very essence of the soul & 
          <lb/>surerr than those of matter—for some say, there is 
          <lb/>
                  <hi rend="underline()">no body</hi>. In <hi rend="underline()">consciousness there can be no delusion</hi>, even 
                <lb/>where <hi rend="underline()">no body nor <del rend="struck(single)">&</del>
                  </hi>
                  <hi rend="underline()">spiri</hi>t in the world. And when concsious
          <lb/>of <subst>
                     <del>motions</del>
                     <add>the</add>
                  </subst> perfections of God, without 
          <choice>
                     <orig>raticiconation</orig>
                     <reg>ratiocination</reg>
                  </choice>, the joy 
          <lb/>is certain & <choice>
                     <orig>infablible</orig>
                     <reg>infallible</reg>
                  </choice>—so of every other sentiment which 
          <lb/>inraptures & ennobles. If <persName key="JB1">Butler</persName> meant these <hi rend="underline()">feelings</hi>, 
          <lb/>when he said somthing (I almost forget) about weaken-
          <lb break="no"/>ing the priciples of action, then I wont believe him, 
          <lb/>
                  <choice>
                     <abbr>tho’</abbr>
                     <expan>though</expan>
                  </choice> I seldom pass a week without trembling at his 
          <lb/>verdict—without desiring <hi rend="underline()">to do</hi>, to act, without the aid of 
          <lb/>feeling. And mayhap the purest virtue is independent. But of
           <pb ed="HM" n="463b"/>
                  <pb ed="GT" n="F33"/>
                  <pb ed="BP" n="13"/>
                  <lb/>what nature is vertue without <hi rend="underline()">consciousness</hi> of it? Does the 
          <lb/>Martyr, the Reformer the Missionary act without feeling 
          <lb/>a stronge <choice>
                     <orig>persusion</orig>
                     <reg>persuasion</reg>
                  </choice> of the truth for <choice>
                     <abbr>w’h</abbr>
                     <expan>which</expan>
                  </choice> he suffers. Does 
          <lb/>he go <choice>
                     <abbr>thro’</abbr>
                     <expan>through</expan>
                  </choice> incalculable sufferings guided only the cool dedu 
          <lb break="no"/>tions of reason & the connection of truth? Probably <persName key="JB1">But-
            <lb break="no"/>ler</persName> meant the proscription of feelings <choice>
                     <abbr>w’h</abbr>
                     <expan>which</expan>
                  </choice> only swims in the 
          <lb/>fancy—never warm the affections nor subdue the passions</seg>

<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" rend="pre()post()underline()" xml:id="ANN016" cert="medium" ana="a:reference" source="b:IT50046">let me dispise my life</quote>

<seg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xml:id="ANN020" cert="low" ana="a:reference" source="bibliography.xml#CampbellandHume_Lectures bibliography.xml#NA_Augsburg_Confession bibliography.xml#Hazelius_Luther"><!-- No bibl entry for Hazelius -->I have been reading or rather poring over 
            <lb/>
                  <persName key="ML1">Luther’s</persName> life. What an eternal wittness of the agency of God 
            <lb/>with that of man! His sorrows misgivings & concessions 
            <lb/>to Rome discover the natural workings of man. His 
            <lb/>daring courage, his miraculous faith (without the <hi rend="underline()">show</hi>
                  <lb/>of miricle) bespeake the agency of God without a doubt. 
            <lb/>How much richer a gift, how much more adapted to the 
            <lb/>condition of man was the reformation by apparent (and in 
            <lb/>some reality) by human methods than by miricle! The for-
            <lb break="no"/>mation of <persName key="ML1">Luther’s</persName> mind was ordained by God as a means of 
            <lb/>it, yet how many causes natural & coporeal were in the
            <lb/>chain!</seg>

<seg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xml:id="an263.1506" ana="a:reference" source="b:IT50060">obedience raises me by his
                    <lb/>hand to walk on the waves with him</seg>

<seg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xml:id="an307.44" cert="low" source="b:IT50011" ana="a:reference">
                                <hi rend="underline()">I</hi>
                                <lb/>have been weake for many moments. God most holy I
                      <lb/>plead thy promises— I bring the arguments of my misery
                      <lb break="no"/>—do more for me—crushed by exteriors—appear for my
                      <lb/>spirit—if I cannot serve thee—<hi rend="underline()">love thee</hi> and
                      <lb/>fear thee I do not wish for any mode of existence.
                      <lb/>If I cannot glorify thee in life let me die to honor thee
                      <lb/>die and perceive thee—know order & forever & un-
                      <lb break="no"/>ceasingly obey it. Perhaps my pride suffers—perhaps
                      <lb/>were I larger these failures would not pain me so—
                      <lb/>While mortal I shall sin— I do not wish to be other
                      <lb/>than human—for then I <choice>
                                   <abbr>s<hi rend="sup() underline()">d</hi>
                     </abbr>
                                   <expan>should</expan>
                                </choice> be <app>
                                   <lem>without</lem>
                                   <rdg wit="#rwe" wms:loc="2B.264">out of</rdg>
                                </app> the pale of <choice>
                                   <abbr>xianity</abbr>
                                   <expan>christianity</expan>
                                </choice>
                                <lb/>—blessed province <choice>
                                   <abbr>w’h</abbr>
                                   <expan>which</expan>
                                </choice> binds the redeemed nearer the
                    <lb/>throne of the Creator! Perhaps, here Paul <hi rend="underline()">gloried in</hi>
                                <lb/>
                                <hi rend="underline()">infirmity</hi>.</seg>

<seg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xml:id="an323.334" cert="low" source="b:IT50048" ana="a:reference">
                                       <hi rend="underline()">the honor that com
                        <lb break="no"/>eth from God</hi>
               </seg>

<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" source="bibliography.xml#Robinson_Scripture">If a man love me</quote>

<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" source="bibliography.xml#Robinson_Scripture">turns all his attention
			       <lb/>to render his duties just, complete, beautifull & strongly
			       <lb/>expressive of the inward esteem from <choice>
			                  <abbr>w’h</abbr>
			                  <expan>which</expan>
			               </choice> they flow;
			       <lb/>and he endeavours to give his morality a refinement &
			       <lb/>delicacy suited to the nature of that grand & noble virtue
			       <lb/>from <choice>
			                  <abbr>w’h</abbr>
			                  <expan>which</expan>
			               </choice> it proceeds.</quote>
